original_solution_mapping.L1: Joe can buy a game for $50 and sell it for $30, so he is losing $50 - $30 = $<<50-30=20>>20 each month when he buys and sells a game.
original_solution_mapping.L2: Joe starts out with $240 and he buys a game and sells a game he loses $20 per month, so it will take $240/$20 = <<240/20=12>>12 months until he is out of money.

original_function_code:
def solve():
    """Index: 5523.
    Returns: the number of months Joe can buy and sell games before running out of money.
    """
    # L1
    cost_to_buy_game = 50 # spends $50 a month on video games
    price_to_sell_game = 30 # sells his games for $30 each
    monthly_loss = cost_to_buy_game - price_to_sell_game

    # L2
    initial_money = 240 # starts with $240
    months_until_out_of_money = initial_money / monthly_loss

    # FA
    answer = months_until_out_of_money
    return answer

logical_steps.solution_line_template: Joe can buy a game for ${cost_to_buy_game} and sell it for ${price_to_sell_game}, so he is losing ${cost_to_buy_game} - ${price_to_sell_game} = $<<{cost_to_buy_game}-{price_to_sell_game}={monthly_loss}>>{monthly_loss} each month when he buys and sells a game.

Joe starts out with ${initial_money} and he buys a game and sells a game he loses ${monthly_loss} per month, so it will take ${initial_money}/${monthly_loss} = <<{initial_money}/{monthly_loss}={months_until_out_of_money}>>{months_until_out_of_money} months until he is out of money.

flawed_nl_reconstruction.L1: Joe can buy a game for $50 and sell it for $30, so he is losing $50 - $30 = $<<50-30=20>>20 each month when he buys and sells a game.
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L2: Joe starts out with $240 and he buys a game and sells a game he loses $20 per month, so it will take $240/$20 = <<240/20=4800>>4800 months until he is out of money.

explanation: Incorrect operation. The calculation should use '/' but used '*' instead.
